Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Geochemical Study of the Nature and Evolution of Mantle Upwelling Beneath Ross Island and its Relationship to Tectonics in the West Antarctica Rift System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Existing petrologic and geochemical data for Ross Island volcanic centers are sparse and outdated, with the exception of the well-studied Mt. Erebus stratovolcano. Therefore, understanding of the genesis, evolution and tectonic context of alkaline magmatism on Ross Island is extremely limited. The PIs propose to conduct a field and laboratory based geochemical, isotopic, and petrologic study to investigate alkaline volcanism across the entirety of Ross Island. This study will provide: state-of-the-art isotopic abundances of Nd, Sr, Hf and Pb; pre-eruptive volatile concentrations as determined in melt inclusion studies; petrological and mineralogical information, and major and trace element concentrations for samples from Mt. Terror, Mt.Bird and Hut Point Peninsula. When combined with the published compositional and isotopic data from Mount Erebus, and the published Ar-Ar ages from Ross Island, these data will provide essential information on the nature of the mantle source and the processes and causes of magma genesis beneath Ross Island.

Broader impacts:
This proposal will train two PhD students, broaden the participation of underrepresented groups, promote and enhance secondary educational experiences in a formal class room setting, and encourage new investigators to become involved in USAP. The proposed research includes a collaboration with ENS, Lyon, France. This study will also establish a suite of well-described and geochemically well-characterized samples available to other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ross Island is a large, high volcanic island in the southwestern Ross Sea of Antarctica. The island started forming about 4 million years ago and at its center is the 12,500 foot high Mount Erebus volcano. Erebus volcano is the southernmost active volcano on Earth. Erebus started forming about 1 million years ago and in terms of size is the 18th largest active volcano on Earth. Surrounding Erebus are 3 major volcanic centers (Mt Bird, Mt Terror and Hut Point Peninsula) that are most older than Erebus. A major question is what was the driving force for such large volumes of young volcanism in this part of Antarctica and what was the nature of the eruptions that formed Ross Island. It had been proposed that major upwelling from deep in the earth's mantle by a cylindrical hot plume was the driving force behind the origin of the volcanic rocks forming Ross Island and also responsible for the radial distribution of the volcanic centers around Erebus.

Volatile molecules like H2O and CO2 play an important role in the properties of  molten magma stored in the earth's crust. Volatiles are responsible for controlling the size and style of volcanic eruptions. We examined the pre-eruptive concentrations of volatiles in the magmas that erupted to form Ross Island. Crystals of the magnesium-iron silicate mineral olivine are amongst the first to grow in magma reservoirs deep within the earth's crust and upper mantle. As the crystals grow they can trap small blebs of the molten magma (often called melt) inside the crystal and these melt inclusions can be found and analyzed once they have erupted. Melt inclusions are time capsules and hold a wealth of information and provide insight into the mantle source of the magma and the conditions responsible for the formation of the magma by melting of the solid upper mantle rocks. In this study around 100 melt inclusions were analyzed for many components like the volatiles (H2O, CO2, F, Cl, S), major components (SiO2, Al2O3, FeO, MgO etc) and trace components (Rb, Sr, Ce, Th etc) and compared to older studies done on melt inclusions in crystals from lavas erupted from Erebus volcano.

The stunning discovery of this work is the exceedingly high CO2 concentrations (up to 1.8 weight %) in some of the melt inclusions. We believe these are the highest ever measured in melt inclusions from basaltic rocks. This has important implications to the mechanism of formation of the parental basaltic magmas and the depth where the magma started to crystallize the olivine. We inferred from the melt inclusions in rocks, originally erupted below sea level and cored by drilling at Hut Point Peninsula, that there was a magma chamber below Hut Point at 18 km. By modeling the diffusive loss of hydrogen ions (H+) from the melt inclusions, it is shown that the magmas ascended from 18 km in less than a year. Melt inclusions from Terror and Bird lack evidence of diffusive loss of H+ and apparently rose to the surface more slowly. Also, the melt inclusions from Bird and Terror are chemically variable and show that there a significant mixing of many magma types in crustal storage areas. Low H2O (0.1 wt %) and CO2 (0-0.2 wt %) contents in melt inclusions from Erebus rocks indicate they underwent shallow (<6 km) crystallization before eruption, probably in a large magma storage reservoir (often referred to as a magma chamber). Magma chambers are the heart of a volcano and their nature plays a critical role in how and when a volcano erupts.
